Network Working Group M. Kerwin Network Working Group M. Kerwin
Internet-Draft June 2, 2016 Internet-Draft October 12, 2017
Intended status: Standards Track Intended status: Standards Track
Expires: December 4, 2016 Expires: April 15, 2018
HTTP/2 "Dropped Frame" Frame HTTP/2 "Dropped Frame" Frame
draft-kerwin-http2-nak-frame-00 draft-kerwin-http2-nak-frame-01
Abstract Abstract
This document defines an extension to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol This document defines an extension to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol
Version 2 (HTTP/2) that allows for non-destructive signalling of Version 2 (HTTP/2) that allows an endpoint to signal to its peer that
unsupported extension frames. an unsupported extension frame was discarded.

<http://phluid61.github.io/internet-drafts/http2-nak-frame/>

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Out of the box, the Hypertext Transfer Protocol Version 2 (HTTP/2) Out of the box, the Hypertext Transfer Protocol Version 2 (HTTP/2)
[RFC7540] makes provision for extension frame types to be sent on a [RFC7540] makes provision for extension frames to be sent on a
connection, with or without prior agreement from either or both connection, with or without prior agreement from either peer, with
peers, with the assertion that "implementations MUST discard frames the assertion that "implementations MUST discard frames that have
that have unknown or unsupported types" ([RFC7540], Section 5.5). unknown or unsupported types" ([RFC7540], Section 5.5). However it
However it can be useful to explicitly notify the peer if such a can be useful to explicitly notify the peer if such a frame is
frame is discarded. discarded.
This document defines an extension to HTTP/2 that allows a peer to This document defines an extension to HTTP/2 that allows a peer to
signal that a received frame was discarded, without altering the signal that a received frame was discarded, without altering the
stream or connection state ([RFC7540], Section 5.1), and in stream or connection state ([RFC7540], Section 5.1), and in
particular without triggering an error condition. particular without triggering an error condition.
1.1. Notational Conventions 1.1. Notational Conventions
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119]. "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP
14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all
capitals, as shown here.
2. Additions to HTTP/2 2. Additions to HTTP/2
This document introduces a new HTTP/2 frame type ([RFC7540], This document introduces a new HTTP/2 frame type ([RFC7540],
Section 11.2). Section 11.2).
2.1. DROPPED_FRAME 2.1. DROPPED_FRAME
DROPPED_FRAME frames (type code=0xTBA) can be sent on a connection at DROPPED_FRAME frames (type code=0xTBA) can be sent on a connection at
any time to indicate that a received frame was discarded without any any time after the connection preface except in the middle of a
action being taken. header block ([RFC7540], Section 4.3) to indicate that a received
extension frame was discarded without any other action being taken.
+---------------+ +---------------+
| Type (8) | | Type (8) |
+---------------+ +---------------+
DROPPED_FRAME Frame Payload DROPPED_FRAME Frame Payload
The DROPPED_FRAME frame contains a single 8-bit integer containing The DROPPED_FRAME frame contains a single 8-bit integer containing
the value of the Type field from the discarded frame. the value of the Type field from the discarded frame.
The DROPPED_FRAME frame does not define any flags. The DROPPED_FRAME frame does not define any flags.
An endpoint SHOULD send a DROPPED_FRAME frame for an unknown or An endpoint SHOULD send a DROPPED_FRAME frame for an unknown or
unsupported frame type the first time it discards such a frame. unsupported extension frame type the first time it discards a frame
of that type.
An endpoint MAY send a DROPPED_FRAME frame for a particular incoming An endpoint MAY send a DROPPED_FRAME frame for a particular frame
frame type only once, even if it discards multiple frames of that type only once, even if it discards multiple frames of that type.
type.
An endpoint that receives a DROPPED_FRAME frame ought to take it as An endpoint that receives a DROPPED_FRAME frame ought to take it as
an indication that the extension is not supported by the peer, and an indication that the extension is not supported by the peer, and
MAY subsequently choose to not send further frames of that type to or MAY subsequently choose not to send further frames of that type or to
to enter into extension negotiations with the peer. attempt extension negotiation with the peer.
Receipt of a DROPPED_FRAME frame does not necessarily mean that all
frames on that connection with the discarded type will be discarded
in future. A transparent intermediary that forwards an extension
frame in one direction and a corresponding DROPPED_FRAME frame in the
other direction MUST NOT intercept future frames of that type and
preemptively reply with a DROPPED_FRAME frame.
DROPPED_FRAME frames are not associated with any individual stream. DROPPED_FRAME frames are not associated with any individual stream.
If a DROPPED_FRAME frame is received with a stream identifier field If a DROPPED_FRAME frame is received with a stream identifier field
value other than 0x0, the recipient MUST respond with a connection value other than 0x0, the recipient MUST respond with a connection
error ([RFC7540], Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR. error ([RFC7540], Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
Receipt of a DROPPED_FRAME frame with a length field value other than Receipt of a DROPPED_FRAME frame with a length field value other than
1 MUST be treated as a connection error ([RFC7540], Section 5.4.1) of 1 MUST be treated as a connection error ([RFC7540], Section 5.4.1) of
type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR. type FRAME_SIZE_ERROR.
An endpoint MUST NOT send a DROPPED_FRAME frame with a Type of
DROPPED_FRAME (0xTBA). If a DROPPED_FRAME frame is received with a
Type field value of 0xTBA, the recipient MUST respond with a
connection error ([RFC7540], Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.
Extensions that define new HTTP/2 frame types MAY specify behaviours
in response to DROPPED_FRAME frames with those types, however
extensions that change the semantics of existing protocol components,
including those defined in this document, MUST be negotiated before
being used ([RFC7540], Section 5.5).
3. Security Considerations 3. Security Considerations
Receipt of a DROPPED_FRAME frame does not guarantee that the sending
peer will send one for every frame type it drops, and the absence of
a DROPPED_FRAME frame does not imply that the peer has not discarded
a frame. Implementations MUST NOT depend on the use of DROPPED_FRAME
frames to indicate acceptance or rejection of extension frames.
4. IANA Considerations 4. IANA Considerations
This document updates the registriy for frame types in the "Hypertext This document updates the registry for frame types in the "Hypertext
Transfer Protocol (HTTP) 2 Parameters" section. Transfer Protocol (HTTP) 2 Parameters" section.
4.1. HTTP/2 Frame Type Registry Update 4.1. HTTP/2 Frame Type Registry Update
This document updates the "HTTP/2 Frame Type" registry ([RFC7540], This document updates the "HTTP/2 Frame Type" registry ([RFC7540],
Section 11.2). The entries in the following table are registered by Section 11.2). The entries in the following table are registered by
this document. this document.
